example: How much money do you need to get by each day?
How often do you get away from it all?
When was the last time you got into trouble?
When was the last time you got together with your friends?
Have you ever done something wrong and gotten away with it?
What did you get up to last weekend?
What time do you usually get up?
What do you do after you get up?
What would you like to get rid of in your house?
How long does it take you to get to class?
What do you usually do to get over a big disappointment?
What do you do when you can't get through to someone on the phone?
What was the last time you did something wrong and got off lightly?
When was the last time you got wound up?
What lies have you told to get out of doing something?
Have you ever had problems getting down from somewhere?
How well do you get on with everyone in your family?

translate: не обращая внимания ни на что

example: My father was dismissed from hospital

translate: прибыль (полученная в результате конкуренции с кем-либо)

example: It sounds familiar

translate: смыть (с себя в душе грязь и т.п.)
смывать (с себя в душе грязь и т.п.)

example: The bulk of consumers are based in towns.
He a was short agreeable chap.

dictionary.description: Used to change the subject, to say something that you have just thought about and that doesn't have to be connected to what was being said before.
example: Well, it has been a very productive meeting, don't you think? By the way/Incidentally, what time is it?
I'll try to fix my car this afternoon. By the way/Incidentally, do you still have that screwdriver that I lent you?

dictionary.description: Used to change the subject, to say something that you have just thought about and that doesn't have to be connected to what was being said before.
example: Well, it has been a very productive meeting, don't you think? By the way/Incidentally, what time is it?
I'll try to fix my car this afternoon. By the way/Incidentally, do you still have that screwdriver that I lent you?

dictionary.description: Used to introduce information that might be in some way surprising or unexpected.
example: I don't really like chicken. Actually a matter of fact I have only eaten chicken once in my life.
Everybody thinks he has a very bad temper, but actually a matter of fact he is very kind.

dictionary.description: Used to introduce information that might be in some way surprising or unexpected.
example: I don't really like chicken. In fact I have only eaten chicken once in my life.
Everybody thinks he has a very bad temper, but in fact he is very kind.

dictionary.description: Used to introduce information that might be in some way surprising or unexpected.
example: I don't really like chicken. As a matter of fact I have only eaten chicken once in my life.
Everybody thinks he has a very bad temper, but as a matter of fact he is very kind.

dictionary.description: Used to return to an earlier subject after a digression, or to get to the most interesting point. Used to give a more important reason for something you are saying.
example: It's not so strange to lose documents. It happens to lots of people all the time. Anyway, we finally found the passports in …
I'm too tired to go and it's too late, and anyway it's too expensive.

dictionary.description: Used to return to an earlier subject after a digression, or to get to the most interesting point. Used to give a more important reason for something you are saying.
example: It's not so strange to lose documents. It happens to lots of people all the time. In any case, we finally found the passports in …
I'm too tired to go and it's too late, and in any case it's too expensive.

dictionary.description: Used to return to an earlier subject in the conversation after an interruption or digression.
example: As I was saying, we could get up early and spend the whole day there.

dictionary.description: Used to introduce an additional point that supports or explains what you have just said. Used to say that something is true despite what is believed or said.
example: I might understand her better than you, after all, she is my wife.
Don't be too hard on him. After all, he is just a kid.
He is not such a bad professional after all.

dictionary.description: Used to introduce positive information when talking about something negative. Used to reduce the effect of something we have said, or to make something less certain or definite.
example: Lots of people got injured in the accident, but at least nobody died.
I finished last in the race, but at least I finished.
He knows the president, or at least that's what he says.

translate: подводя итог изложенному выше, отметим следующее
dictionary.description: Taking into consideration all the parts of a situation.
example: There were some mistakes, but all in all, you did a pretty good job.
Both TVs are great, but all in all, I think this one is better for you.

dictionary.description: Generally
example: On the whole, men tend to avoid talking about feelings.
There has been some criticism, but on the whole, customers like what we offer.

dictionary.description: Used to add additional information (informal)
example: I think it's a wonderful place, besides, it's very cheap.

dictionary.description: Used to add additional (an often more important) information (formal)
example: Electric cars are becoming more powerful and energy-efficient. Furthermore, they are much cheaper than a few years ago.

dictionary.description: We use what's more to add something interesting to what we have just said. It's similar to furthermore but more informal.
example: Scientists have found a big body of water under the surface of the planet. What's more, they think it's not the only body of water they are going to find.
He said that the new season is going to be premiered this September and, what's more, he confirmed that it's not going to be the last.

dictionary.description: Used to introduce a fact that is easy to see or understand.
example: Obviously, without qualifications it's harder to get a good job.

dictionary.description: Used to introduce the most important point or characteristic of something.
example: Basically, what we do here is produce the plastic parts of the phone.

dictionary.description: Used to say what has been said in simpler words.
example: She said we should take a break and have time to ourselves, in other words, she dumped me.

dictionary.description: Used to explain or be more precise about something we have said. Similar to in other words.
example: The best thing about music is its repeatability, that is to say, you can listen to the same songs again and again and never get bored.

dictionary.description: Used after an order or suggestion to say what will happen if that order or suggestion is not followed.
example: Be here at 8 o'clock, otherwise, you will miss your turn.

dictionary.description: About. Used to introduce a topic of conversation.
example: Regarding the new player, we'll have to decide if or when to sell him.

dictionary.description: About. Used to introduce a topic of conversation.
example: As regards the new player, we'll have to decide if or when to sell him.

dictionary.description: About. Used to introduce a topic of conversation.
example: As far as the new player is concerned, …

dictionary.description: Used to introduce a contrasting fact. It can be preceded by on the one hand.
example: Cycling is good for your health, and it's a sport that is gentle with your muscles and joints. But on the other hand, there are many fatal accidents among cyclists.
On the one hand, cycling is good for your health, and it's a sport that is gentle with your muscles and joints. But on the other hand, there are many fatal accidents among cyclists.

dictionary.description: We use whereas to compare and contrast two things or ideas. It means 'while' when it is used to express contrast.
example: The north is cold whereas the south is very hot.
Whereas people used to aspire to have a big house, kids, dog etc., nowadays preferences are tending more towards apartments.
